Speaker: will
Dialogue: I don't need to look at it.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: Nothing wrong with smelling the roses.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I don't babysit any more, Mr. Angstrom. Just made detective three weeks ago.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Detective Eckhart!  I know!  Welcome to Nightmute!

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I just want to say how incredible it is to have you working with us, Detective Dormer.  I've followed all your cases. Theodore Dineli, Frank and Casey Prud'homme, the Port Angeles shootings...

Speaker: pilot
Dialogue: Tell your dad the game's gonna start late this week, Ellie.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I just made detective three weeks ago.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: Christ.  I haven't seen you boys since...

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: Seven years?  Where does it all go?  That was some amazing time, though, wasn't it?

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: I knew that was coming.  I deserve it.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: Got a love affair with police work. Drives me crazy with it.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Keeping you busy up here, Charlie?

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: I told you seven years ago this was a stepping stone to retirement.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: What's the D.A. got them on?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Four unwarranted shootings, witness intimidation, and cocaine theft.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: How about you?  How you faring?

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: I.A.'s calling themselves the "Corruption Task Force."  Can you believe that? Trying to root out any mistakes or "oversights" any other Detectives may have made over the years.  They're turning it into a witch hunt.  Something on the news about it practically every night.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: Got a bunch of messages here from some guy named Warfield.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: Wants me to keep him posted on all your movements up here.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: Couldn't get a thing from the body.  Not a trace.  Town's never dealt with anything like this before.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: This is Detective Dormer and his partner Detective Eckhart.  On loan from Buck Lundgard, Seattle Robbery and Homicide Special Branch.  They'll be helping with the Connell case.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: This is Detective Fred Duggar.  He's been leading the investigation up to now.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Suppose you want to see the body.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Guess that's what they call Alaskan hospitality.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Like I said, no.  We know about those things up here.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: He knew exactly what we'd be looking for. Made sure to cover up all his tracks.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: You're not from here.  I can tell by your walk.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Detectives Will Dormer and Hap Eckhart. There should be a reservation for us.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Alaskan summers.  Hope you're an easy sleeper.  It'll be like this all night.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: See you have the same decor as my room.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: We'll talk when we get back to Seattle.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: When's that, a week?  Two weeks?...  We have to figure out a plan of action now.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You know my plan of action.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: Dammit, Will.  Warfield had me locked up in his office again for five hours yesterday.  Five hours.  Asking all kinds of questions...

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: But he's zeroing in on me.  On us. Everyone's talking about it.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: Well, I gotta tell you.  With a wife, three kids, and a pension plan in the balance, it's rattling hard.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: We say nothing.  It goes away.  Simple as that.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: Look.  We've tampered with evidence. We've pushed witnesses.  We've planted shit.  And they're sniffing around like dogs.  Especially on the Dobbs case...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Weston Dobbs killed an eight year-old boy and left him hanging in the basement like a piece of meat.  You remember that?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: One word to I.A. and he walks.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: Maybe not.  We could talk to Buck...

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: Cut some kind of a deal.  I heard that's what Flynn's doing...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Mike Flynn's a dirty cop, Hap!  We are nothing like Mike Flynn.  We did what we needed to do to make sure that son-of- bitch Dobbs paid for what he did.  And every bastard like him.  We say one word about it and every case we ever brought in is going to blow wide open and they'll all walk.  Every last one.  And I am not going to let that happen.  No deals.  No compromises.  No discussions.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: Goddammit, Will.  You grab on to something and you don't let it go.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: I don't know if it's because you think it's the right thing to do or because your pride won't let you do anything else.  I can't tell any more.  But I can tell you one thing.  I'm getting too old for this cowboy cop stuff.  Breaking the rules.  Cleaning up messes.  We're a dying breed, Will. You're a dying breed.  I.A., the D.A., all those reporters - they don't care what you did at Leland Street seven years ago.  They don't care that you've made this your life.  They don't care about getting the bad guy...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You got to be kidding me.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Fred wants us to meet him at the Connell's.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Brought you a bear claw.  Just in case you were hungry.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Oh.  You know.  Small-time stuff. Nothing like what you must get.  Mostly drinking-related problems.  Domestic abuse.  Barroom fights.  Stuff like that.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Don't give misdemeanors a bad rap.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: But they're so boring.  All small stuff.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It's all about the small stuff.  Small lies.  Small mistakes.  Small oversights. People give themselves away in a traffic violation just as much as they do in a murder case.  It's human nature.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Typical seventeen year-old.  She went to a party Friday night?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Down at a local dive the kids like to hang out in.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: She left the party early.  Friends said she had a fight with her boyfriend and stormed out.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Who was the last one to see her alive?

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Randy Stetz.  Her boyfriend.  We've questioned him, searched his place. Didn't find anything.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: These are designer.  Expensive.  Could Randy Stetz afford these?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Well her mother didn't buy them for her.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You don't seem all that sad.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: I haven't had a chance!  You fuckers been all over my back since Monday!

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: You know smoking stunts your growth.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Kay Connell.  Did you love her?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: "She was nice."  Wow.  That makes me all soft inside.  Ever occur to you she didn't love you back?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: She loved me.  She wanted to see me every night.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: But she was seeing someone else on the side.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: I don't know what you're fucking talking about.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Friday night, at the party - what'd you fight about?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Just stuff.  I don't fucking remember.

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: I told you I don't remember.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: After that she left the party to go to him.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Ran like hell to go to him...

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: Fuck you, man! - I'm sick of all your fucking cop questions...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Now you listen to me, you little shit. This fuck-the-world-Metallica-t-shirt crap may work with your mamma, but it doesn't work with me.  You got mad at your girlfriend because she was seeing someone else.  You want to be the last person who saw her alive or are you going to tell me who that is?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: He's a little surly, isn't he?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I want you to check this out, Ellie.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: The small things - remember?  The second you're about to dismiss something - look at it again.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: You want me to write that down?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: The bartender at Darrow's.  He was there Friday night.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Halibut Calabrese.  Halibut Olympia. Halibut Cajun Style.  Halibut fish and chips...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Looks like the natives are restless.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: I wish I could stick it out like you.  I just, with Trish and the kids...

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: I'm thinking I could get off with probation.  Keep half my pension.  That's all I want.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Goddammit, Hap.  Think about what you're doing...

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: You don't have to be involved, Will.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You tell Buck and I'm involved whether I like it or not...

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: Hey - you do everything around here?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I'll just have another Scotch in my room.  If you don't mind.

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: I read that kind of crap.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Read them.  Tell me anything that strikes you.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: I'll stick it in the evidence locker...

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: Uh, right.  About two miles outside of town.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Why are we taking it back?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: This murder was in the papers, right?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Call all of them from here to Anchorage. Tell them we now know that Kay Connell left the party with a dark blue knapsack, but we haven't recovered it yet.  We can get it in by the morning editions.

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: Glock 40.  All plastic save the barrel and firing pin.  Never rusts.  What do you carry down in Seattle?

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: Maybe this guy doesn't read the papers.

Speaker: hap
Dialogue: Or goes straight to the Sports Section.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: And then I lost him.  In the fog.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: About how long 'til you heard the suspect's second shot?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Twenty, thirty seconds.  I followed the sound down to the water.  That's where...

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: I think you need a glass of this.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Why didn't I know about that goddamn tunnel, Charlie?

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: There's a bunch of those tunnels out there, Will.  From bunkers over sixty years old.  I don't even know half of them myself, and I grew up here.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I had him, Charlie.  Right in front of me.  Not two feet.  I could smell the son- of-a-bitch.  Playing with me.  And I missed the shot.  He was right there and I missed the shot!  Then my goddamned gun jammed...

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: It's only gonna make you crazy.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: But what about the Connell case?  I'm on the Connell case.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: We need paperwork, Ellie.  You know that. Just write up a quick report.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I'm going to check on the roadblocks...

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: You're no good right now, Will.  Go back to the Lodge.  Try to get some rest.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: ...earlier this evening after an aborted attempt to apprehend a suspect.  He was forty-five...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You were nice to him.  He liked you.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Hold on a second.  He's right here.

Speaker: warfield's voice
Dialogue: Detective Dormer.  I've been trying to reach you.  I was very sorry to hear about your partner, Detective Eckhart. It must have been a terrible shock, what happened this morning.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: That's not exactly how I'd put it.

Speaker: warfield's voice
Dialogue: Oh, nothing.  Just that I felt Detective Eckhart and I, Hap and I, were starting to make a real connection before you left.  I sensed that he was ready to get some things off his chest.  Did you sense anything like that, Detective?  I mean, as his partner?...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You know why everyone hates you, Warfield?  It's not your questions, it's not your press conferences, it's not even your cheap suits; everyone hates you 'cause day after day you suck the marrow out of real cops when you never had the balls to become one yourself.  Well I got to tell you, it's a shame you're not up here with me because I'd love to show you right now just what a real cop is capable of.  You just remember that when you're sitting at your bullshit desk reading your bullshit report on my dead partner!

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: ...Nightmute hasn't lost an officer in thirty-seven years, and even though Detective Eckhart wasn't from here, he was as good as one of us on this case.  I had the honor of working with him down in Seattle for a number of years.  He was a fine detective and an even better man.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: Okay.  Then let's get to it.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It's good to be accurate, Ellie.  You're doing your job.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I'm so sorry about what happened.  I know you did everything you could...

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Dormer.  Still no sign of the bullet that went through Farrell.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I'm going to the hospital to talk to him now.  You get the search party together.  No fewer than thirty people.  I'll meet you in exactly twenty-five minutes.  Don't waste any time.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Partner or no partner.  That guy's a prick.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: He has to be a prick, Fred.  He's a great detective.

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: Oh, a real tear-jerker.  Brody, the good guy, just got shot.

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: I wish I'd had the chance to get to know him better.  Take him fishing or something.

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: We just gotta catch the bastard, right?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: That's why I'm here.  I need to know exactly what you saw yesterday, Farrell.

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: Pretty much nothing.  That fog was so thick.  The bullet seemed to come out of nowhere.  I don't even remember seeing any shapes.  Then I saw you.  But only when you came up close.  Then you disappeared again.  I guess I heard more than I saw.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: No.  No.  Don't be sorry.  It's not your fault.

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: Lonnie and I went to high school together.

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: Oh, you know.  Don't feel that much. Bullet went right through.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Right.  Got lost in the rocks.

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: We'll get the other one, though.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: You're supposed to be Farrell.  Shot in the thigh and writhing in pain.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Accuracy.  That's what.  Now get down.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: ...shortly after hearing the second shot, Detective Dormer continued through the water until he spotted the body, lying approximately fifteen feet away.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: The woods.  One group heading south, the other heading north.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Alright.  Go back and set up some follow- ups for this afternoon.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: You don't think they should start further back?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: He had to have exited here.  Over those boulders.  I saw him move, he's nimble. Would have taken the hardest way out.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I got it.  Don't know why I bother.  It's been broken for two years.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: No.  He didn't say what his name was. Only that you were expecting him.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Short.  Dark hair.  Not that memorable.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I could say the same thing about you.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Oh.  We always have play-offs in the middle of the night.  It's the best time.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: The Puffins and the Hawks.  We're in extra innings.  The Hawks have a really good line-up this year.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: No.  Well.  I had a brother.  He died when I was eleven.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It's okay.  Happened a long time ago.  He was killed in a fire.  In New Mexico.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: That must have been awful for you.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Not really.  Nice kid, huh?  Just kept making up more and more lies...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I'm going back to the Lodge, Ellie. Still need to go through some of Kay Connell's school records.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Duggar - I'm at the coroner's now.  I'll be back in about twenty minutes...

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: Detective.  Thought you were sending one of your lackeys.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I thought it was better if I came.  Under the circumstances.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: It's different when you know them, isn't it?  Just sign over there and she's all yours.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: You're looking a little green, Detective.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: What's with all the moose antlers around here?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: First I need a copy of the key.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: This isn't Seattle, Detective.  We don't have copies.  This is the only one.

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: I bet you haven't been getting much sleep.

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: You lower-48s.  You think the white nights are kind of neat.  Then you can't sleep for days.  I've seen it happen about a million times.  But you can't sleep for a different reason.

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: I saw what really happened, Will...

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: I saw you kill your partner.  With your back-up weapon.  Out there on the beach. I saw you shoot him dead...

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: Don't worry.  I won't tell anyone.  Oh, and I saw you take my gun.  My uncle's old 357.  I dropped it in the rocks. But you can go ahead and keep that.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: You look like you're in a hurry.  I just wanted to ask you about these pictures.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: But here's the thing.  I retraced your exact steps according to your statement. You couldn't have seen Detective Eckhart from there.  I mean, not in that fog.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: How much closer would you say you were?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Listen, Ellie.  I don't have time for this shit.  Five feet, seven feet, twenty feet.  Put down whatever you want in your report, alright?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: These should have gone out two hours ago.

Speaker: young girl
Dialogue: ...And that's how I think Kay would want us to remember her...

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: We should go say hello to Mrs. Connell.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You go ahead.  I'll be there in a second.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Good to see you, too, Randy.

Speaker: tanya
Dialogue: I never met anyone from Seattle before.

Speaker: tanya
Dialogue: What are you doing in this shit-hole town?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You were good friends with Kay Connell, weren't you?

Speaker: tanya
Dialogue: We were like sisters.  Knew everything about each other.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Must be tough for you.  What happened.

Speaker: tanya
Dialogue: Everybody says I'm holding up great, considering.  Don't even care if I go to school.  They're all worried I haven't cried yet.

Speaker: tanya
Dialogue: Do we have to talk about Kay?  I don't want to talk about her right now.  Let's just drive.  Go somewhere.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You want me to take you somewhere?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: How about this.  You like this?

Speaker: tanya
Dialogue: You crazy son-of-a-bitch!  You could have killed us!

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You and Kay were like sisters?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Told each other everything.  That why your picture's torn up in the top drawer of her bureau?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Who was Kay seeing besides Randy Stetz?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: But you were such good friends...

Speaker: tanya
Dialogue: It was like some big fucking secret!

Speaker: tanya
Dialogue: She kept saying she was gonna get out of here.  Leave us all behind.  That he was going to take her!

Speaker: tanya
Dialogue: She used some stupid code name.

Speaker: bedroom
Dialogue: Single bed.  Books and magazines.  A half-eaten tuna sandwich on the bedside table.  "NYPD BLUE" calendar on the wall.  It's quiet.  He walks over to a large DESK by the window. Scattered papers.  Computer.  Mini cassette recorder.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: I beeped you over two hours ago.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: And something else that might interest you.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: One of the paperbacks we found in Kay Connell's knapsack.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Mrs. Connell found this copy in the house.  It's signed.  Personally.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: This is a local writer.  Kay had all his books.  I think we should check it out.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I don't think it'll lead anywhere.

Speaker: old lady
Dialogue: I don't think you should move.

Speaker: old lady
Dialogue: Careful not to bleed on my interior.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: When I was seven my mother and grandmother took me to Vancouver.  We were walking along the street one day when these two men ran past and snatched my grandmother's purse right from under her arm.  Right from under her arm.  That night a police officer came to our hotel room to ask us questions.  Stood the whole time.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: You know this glacier moves a quarter of an inch every day?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You think this is a nice meeting we're having here?  Friendly?  Two people getting acquainted?  Huh?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: That was an accident!  You hear me?  I didn't know it was him!  I didn't know it was him!

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: I figured we're partners on this one.  I mean, after what I saw...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Let's get one thing straight, Byrd.  We are partners on nothing.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: I research my novels.  I know the procedures.  You'd have cuffed me back at the ferry.  You'd have called for back- up, read me my rights, and gotten a search warrant for my apartment.  You're a well-respected detective.  There's no reason for you to be talking to me right now...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You're going to get a phone call.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: I said you're going to get a phone call.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Kay Connell had a signed copy of one of your books.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: You're going to be brought in for questioning.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: Okay.  Okay.  Brought in for questioning. Good.  I can write this.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I needed to get your signature on something.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: About an hour ago.  Said he was more than happy to cooperate.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Isn't that the difference between a good cop and a bad cop?  A good cop can't sleep 'cause a piece of the puzzle's missing.  A bad cop can't sleep 'cause his conscience won't let him.  You said that once, remember?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: No.  But it sounds like something I would've said.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Oh!  I forgot to tell you.  The Puffins won.

Speaker: recorded voice
Dialogue: ...I saw you look right into his eyes and shoot him...

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: You'd have done the same thing, Will.  I know you would...

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: There's a guy down the hall.  Complaining about the noise.  Says he can't sleep.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: The light.  It keeps coming in...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: There was this guy named Weston Dobbs. Twenty-four.  Worked as a part-time stock boy in a copy store.  Every morning he'd sit at the only window in his apartment and watch an eight year-old boy get picked up by his carpool across the street.  And every afternoon he'd watch the boy get dropped off again.  He did this for about six months.  Until one day he got up the nerve to cross the street and grab the boy before his carpool came. Kept him in his apartment for three days. Tortured him.  Raped him.  Made him do things...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Me and Hap.  A year and a half ago.  I knew the second I met Dobbs that he was guilty.  Smug, cold.  Dead eyes.  We had circumstantial evidence, but nothing to tie him to it.  Nothing concrete.  Went over every inch of that apartment.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: We took some blood samples from the boy's body and planted them in his apartment.  Arrested him the next day.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: There've been other cases.  Where we've changed results.  Pushed witnesses. Manipulated evidence.  But Dobbs.  I wanted Dobbs more than anything.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: We're under investigation now.  Back in Seattle.  Hap wanted to talk.  As soon as we got back.  Thought he could work out some kind of deal.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Well, that's not going to happen now.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Do you think it was wrong?  What we did?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: There are two kinds of people in Alaska. Those who were born here and those who've come here to escape something in their lives.  I wasn't born here, Will.  I'm in no position to judge anyone.  I'm not about that any more.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: She was, not quite a "fan."  More an avid reader of my detective novels.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: When did you first meet her?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: A year ago.  At one of my signings.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: She flattered me about my writing.  Asked if she could visit me.  To talk about my books.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: Yes.  Not that much at first.  But then she became more comfortable.  Started visiting me every week...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: What was the nature of your relationship?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: What do you mean, Detective Dormer?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: She was an attractive girl.  Did you have sex with her?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: But she was an attractive girl.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Did you have sex with her?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: I was a mentor to her.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Doesn't sound like a mentor to me.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: I gave her things she didn't have. Couldn't have.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: We understand, Mr. Byrd.  You want to sit down, Detective?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: She wasn't happy.  I was someone to talk to.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Mr. Byrd.  Anything you can tell us could help out with this case.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: She'd come to me, sometimes in the middle of the night.  Bruises all over her back, her upper arms.  I pled with her to let me call the police, but she wouldn't hear it.  Wanted to keep it a secret.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: He has a terrible rage.  Kay even said he carried a handgun around with him.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Margaret!  Get Judge Biggs on the phone!  I'll get another warrant for Stetz's place.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: Could I have some more coffee, Detective Burr?

Speaker: randy
Dialogue: I swear to God.  I didn't kill her.  I swear to God...

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Looks like we can wrap this one up.

Speaker: rich
Dialogue: What do you mean, you can't believe it?

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Didn't you grow up with him?

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: Our dads were on the same boat.  We used to wait for them together.

Speaker: francis
Dialogue: He used to pick fights at the gas station.

Speaker: rich
Dialogue: And remember when he did all those donut holes that one summer?

Speaker: farrell
Dialogue: How do you like our beer?

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: What Detective Dormer needs is a little shut-eye.

Speaker: rich
Dialogue: The white nights been hard on you?

Speaker: francis
Dialogue: They don't have titanium shades over at the Pioneer.

Speaker: francis
Dialogue: You lose all sense of time.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: My people are from Barrow.  Way up north.

Speaker: rich
Dialogue: In the winter there's no sunlight for five straight months.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Like being swallowed up in a black hole.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: Nancy Drew!  Pull up a seat!

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I found this out on the beach.

Speaker: francis
Dialogue: Let it go, Ell.  We got the bad guy.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: None of us carries a 9mm duty weapon.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: It's a legitimate point, isn't it, Detective Dormer?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: The case is closed, Ellie.  I got the next round.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: What the hell are you doing calling me at the station?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: I figured we should touch base.  Compare notes.  I think it went well.  What did you think?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: Told you I could write an ending.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: I thought maybe we could talk some more.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: There's nothing more to talk about.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: But we work so well together...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: We do nothing well together.  Nothing!  You understand me?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: You run on two settings, Will.  I've noticed that...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: What the hell do you know?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: Kay told me.  She comes to me, you know. Tells me things.  About you.  About me.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Don't you pull that shit with me.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: I didn't want to kill her, Will.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: It was when I went to kiss her.  She started laughing.  I got angry.  After all I'd given her.  All I'd shared with her.  I just wanted to make her stop. That's all.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: If you want it to be...

Speaker: will
Dialogue: It took ten minutes to beat Kay Connell to death.  Ten minutes.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: I have a summer house up by Kgun Lake. I'm going to write my next novel there. It's about a famous detective who goes bad.

Speaker: fred
Dialogue: If Spencer's not too drunk to fly.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: Can't talk you into staying for a couple of days?  Do some fishing?  Show you what normally goes on around here.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Had a lot of help from Nightmute's finest.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: Detective Dormer's not leaving for a few hours.

Speaker: chief nyback
Dialogue: Maybe you could drive him to Spencer's.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I would have seen if he came back.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Procedure went out the window a long time ago.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: We're on the same side, Will.  You know that.  After what we've been through together.  We're partners.  Bound by a secret.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: You give the police a bad name, Will.

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: That jammed the last time, remember?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: God, you're a pain in the ass.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I'm going to make a tourniquet.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Walter Byrd killed Kay Connell.  Her things are in the house.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: You shot Detective Eckhart, didn't you?

Speaker: will
Dialogue: No.  But I covered it up.  I lied.

Speaker: will
Dialogue: Because I just couldn't be wrong.  Don't ever get that way, Ellie.  Don't ever lose your way.  It blurs the line.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Don't worry.  I'll have a cool scar.
